Community Hub
Grim Fandango Remastered
One of the most acclaimed adventure games of all time is now back, better than ever. Grim Fandango Remastered has the all the beautiful art and engaging story fans remember, but has also been remastered to look, sound, and control even better than the award-winning original release.
User reviews: Very Positive (1,329 reviews) - 89% of the 1,329 user reviews for this game are positive.
Release Date: Jan 26, 2015

About This Game

Something's rotten in the land of the dead, and you're being played for a sucker. Meet Manny Calavera, travel agent at the Department of Death. He sells luxury packages to souls on their four-year journey to eternal rest. But there's trouble in paradise. Help Manny untangle himself from a conspiracy that threatens his very salvation.

One of the most acclaimed adventure games of all time is now back, better than ever. Grim Fandango's epic story of four years in the life (or death) of Manny Calavera, travel agent to the dead, has been remastered to look, sound, and control even better than when it won GameSpot's Game of the Year award upon its original launch. Grim Fandango still stands as a classic of the genre, with unforgettable characters and unique combination of film noir and Mexican folklore.

Remastered version includes

  • Repainted, hi-res character textures
  • New, dynamic lighting
  • Classic score re-recorded with a full live orchestra
  • Over 2 hours of exclusive developer commentary
  • Concept art browser
READ MORE

JaMyZPunchThis Why u punch you?

7 reviews
Recommended
27.1 hrs on record
Posted: June 26
TIM SCHAFER'S "GRIM FANDANGO”!
There are tons of guides out there. Why you should read mine? I had beat the old version of this video-game around 8 times. Also, I damn love Grim Fandango. Trust me, you will get good info on this one.

This game is one of those that catch your soul and your heart and attach to it like if it will never let you go. It's like if this game eat your soul, but in a good way. In this video-game you are in the shoes of Manuel “Manny” Calavera. You are a travel agent that work for a company called the DOM “Department of the Death” right at the Land of the Death, and your mission is to sell the best commission to the people that came right after death. The objective is to give to each person what deserves for being good or bad in life. The good people go to heaven, but things change when you discover a conspiracy behind the DOM and you meet Mercedes “Merche” Colomar. The world as Manuel Calavera knows it changes forever. Grim Fandango it's a game that contains amazing art, and incredible story and a very fun gameplay.

First, the artists behind this video-game are people that put everything, the best of them to make this video-game possible. Most of them, like most game developers, worked all night to get things done. Passionate people that loved what they were doing and constantly challenged themselves to achieve greatness. The art of Grim Fandango has mixtures of Mexican, Aztec and South American art. It is really interesting to see what the artists did based on that cultures and locations over the world. The scenarios are amazing, the characters are really good developed, and every one of them has a unique personality. This game really feels like an entire new world after the meaning of death. The most exciting thing of this video-game is to discover new places as you progress through the story. It is an amazing feeling to see the new places and its art on each one. This game also is inspired artistically and historically from the famous event from Mexico. "The Day of the Death" which happens on the 2nd of November. If you have an opportunity to travel to Mexico someday. Go for this date and see for yourself the incredible festivities that people do over there. That's a really special day for Mexicans, including me as being Mexican. Now, talking about the Remastered version. This Remaster is really well done, this one has done a pretty good job on remaking the textures to higher resolutions, and fixing the illumination of several characters. The environment looks better in my opinion. Some areas look like the same, but those still today look really well made. It is a little bit hard to detect if there were changes on the environment, but the remastered characters are an instant visual change. Also, the player is able to see the old version by pressing the "backspace" key while in-game. I remember that It doesn't look really fair when you press that key because on my old version. I remember to get textures, and a detail close to the remastered version. Close, but not really like that. It's like the backspace key loads a super low resolution showing you the worst of it. But the Remaster definitely looks great. I love it. Just to finish in this part. I own the 1998 version of Grim Fandango, so I can remember pretty well how it looks.

Second, the story is amazing. It is one of those kind of stories that you wish never ends. In the moment that this story ends, you feel like you want more, but at same time you feel really satisfied with what you went through in this game. Tim Shafter made a really incredible story on this one. It feels like every developer behind this game, from the music to scripting shared a piece of themselves on the final product. This is a spoiler free review of the story. There is an interesting thing about the story, and it is that it feels like it never lacks anything. It has everything one can wish from a really good story. This sentence may differ from a ton of people, but this game don’t was GOTY just because. Also, it contains several references to different noir movies. If you are into a lot of movies of the Noir genre, you will catch a lot of references. The conspiracy feeling, the curiosity and the excitement are always there on this video-game. It is a really well made story. I don't know if I will experiment a video-game like this in the future, but this one stays on my list of favorite video-games of all time.

Third, the gameplay is fun. I like how it is done. There are several control options right now on the Remastered version, but I love to play it at the old style with Tank Controls. The inventory system is super easy. The player goes around the game while recollecting items to accomplish several puzzles. Sometimes the player needs to use certain item more than once to achieve a goal and complete a puzzle. In this game you can run, walk, interact with items, characters and the environment itself. The player can talk to different characters and use several dialogue options to interact with them. Also, this remastered version comes with Steam achievements which makes the replay value to increase a lot from where it was, and it was high. Sometimes it is good to catch a good guide to move forward, because some puzzles are really tricky. Some of those need the player to move to different areas or scenes to accomplish an objective. It is also interesting how every year of the game is made. There are a lot of areas in every year. It almost feels like a small open world video-game. It has limitations, but some of this places are huge, especially in year 2. The interesting thing is how the player keeps to see new and new content over the progress. It doesn't felt repetitive, it doesn't felt recycled. It feels and plays good.

-Inventory System: The player can access the inventory pressing “I” as the default key, and there you choose between multiple items with the left and right arrows. Then, the player selects and item and press “enter” to get it. Finally, the player to get rid of the item needs to press “P” as the default key.
-Tank Controls: This option is a kind of heavy movement. It don’t allows you to move in a fast way. In this case to describe it better it's that the camera don’t moves with you, but you move with the camera. You can see the X scene but you can walk through it only, no camera movement.

Finally, Grim Fandango it's one of those games that catch yourself over the gameplay, the story and its art while making you feel welcome to play it. This was released for the first time in 1998 and the Remastered version was released this year in 2015. A final point to analyze is that you don't need residual VM to play Grim Fandango anymore. This plays well on the new systems. It runs flawlessly on Windows 8.1. Amazing job!

I really apologize for my bad English. I did this review in English and not in Spanish to reach more people. Thank you so much for read.

This game is a damn MASTERPIECE! 10/10
This review was made on: 6/26/2015
JFG

Recommended
13.9 hrs on record
Posted: June 24
Pro & cons
Pros
  • better lighting and shadows
  • better, more detailed, remade textures
  • better, higher poly models
  • fewer bugs
  • runs hassle-free on modern OS and architectures
  • great controller support for X360-compatibile devices

Cons
  • backgrounds are pre-rendered, thus no remaster was possible
  • cutscenes are pre-rendered, thus no remaster was possible
  • soundtrack could've been re-recorded, but then I'd be lamenting how the original one was better
  • voice-overs couldn't be remastered without casting new (and unfamiliar) voice actors
  • still has some bugs

The remaster
Pre-rendered backgrounds can't be remastered or remade (thus, no proper widescreen support here), and even if that was feasible I would rather if they didn't (you'd gain nothing from a wider field of view). So much work has gone into those assets, just listen at the commentary and watch the making-of videos.

Some people define the models as "blocky" because they've never played the original game, nor they have any knowledge about the game itself: models aren't "blocky", it's a stylistic choice (as clearly stated in the commentary) aimed to mimic the mexican paper dolls for the day of the dead. They even considered going 2D because 3D felt too "plastic" back in the day.

Maybe they should've just released it as "Grim Fandango+" or something along those lines to avoid children throwing a fit over "muh remaster". I loved this game back in 1998 and I enjoy having a Windows 8.1 64bit-ready version to run from Steam, hassle-free, with better lighting, models and textures (while keeping it real to the original style), and a behind-the-scenes commentary to boot. It's less than 8$ on sale and barely 15$ any other day. Get a grip.

TL;DR
It was great 17 years ago, it is great today.

I don't see what precisely was "remastered". Compared to really great editions like Monkey Island, this is crap.
Don't get me wrong, the story is great; and I wonder why it has never been made into a movie.
But adding some shades and leaving everything else as it was... I am REALLY disappointed, sorry.

Posted: July 19
This is a glitchy mess. I've already run into two game breaking bugs in two hours. One was a graphical glitch that left artifacts across the screen, and the other froze the game for me. Reloading did nothing.
It's intensely dissatisfying, especially since I've waited years to play this game. The art style is beautiful, the characters are full of personality, and the story seems intriguing, but until they fix these glitches, I cannot recommend this game.

Not Recommended
6.8 hrs on record
Posted: June 8
This game is not in any sense of the word a remaster. It's a port.

There is no denying the quirky charm of the characters or the amount of love and care that has clearly been put into crafting this world, but what about this has been remastered exactly? The character models? Okay. Anything else?

I'm glad that this game hasn't disappeared forever, but don't insult me by calling this a remaster when it looks virtually identical to the original and still contains all of the same bugs. That's lazy.
